texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On most IPv6-enabled networks, network addresses are distributed via  stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC) . That is a fancy way to say that hosts on an IPv6 network will configure their own IP addresses.
texts.text: On most IPv6-enabled networks, network addresses are distributed via  stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC) . That is a fancy way to say that hosts on an IPv6 network will configure their own IP addresses.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The process usually works like this:
texts.text: The process usually works like this:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The host sends out a router solicitation request:
texts.text: The host sends out a router solicitation request:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The router replies with a prefix:
texts.text: The router replies with a prefix:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The host uses its MAC address to generate the remaining bits of the IP address.
texts.text: The host uses its MAC address to generate the remaining bits of the IP address.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The format of the IPv6 address generated by the host is called  EUI-64 . The host takes its MAC address, wedges
texts.text: The format of the IPv6 address generated by the host is called  EUI-64 . The host takes its MAC address, wedges

texts.label: code
texts.orig: FF:FE
texts.text: FF:FE

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: in the middle, and adds the prefix from the router on the front. For much more detail on this process, review the  IEEE's guidelines for EUI-64 . The  Arch Linux wiki page on IPv6  has plenty of detail as well.
texts.text: in the middle, and adds the prefix from the router on the front. For much more detail on this process, review the  IEEE's guidelines for EUI-64 . The  Arch Linux wiki page on IPv6  has plenty of detail as well.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Time to talk security
texts.text: Time to talk security

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: While SLAAC works really well on most networks and provides a highly efficient method for dealing with IP addresses, it can disclose more information about your computer or mobile device than you want to disclose. Websites will see the IPv6 address and they can determine the client's MAC address on networks that are using SLAAC. This could be used for tracking purposes -  both legitimate and illegitimate .
texts.text: While SLAAC works really well on most networks and provides a highly efficient method for dealing with IP addresses, it can disclose more information about your computer or mobile device than you want to disclose. Websites will see the IPv6 address and they can determine the client's MAC address on networks that are using SLAAC. This could be used for tracking purposes -  both legitimate and illegitimate .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Also, bear in mind that the first several bits of a MAC address will often identify the hardware vendor that manufactured your ethernet card or wireless chip. Depending on the vendor, this may expose what type of device you are using (computer or mobile device) and in some cases, which type of computer you are using (Mac vs PC).
texts.text: Also, bear in mind that the first several bits of a MAC address will often identify the hardware vendor that manufactured your ethernet card or wireless chip. Depending on the vendor, this may expose what type of device you are using (computer or mobile device) and in some cases, which type of computer you are using (Mac vs PC).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the worst cases, this information could be used to deliver targeted malware to your device. It could also be used to locate or identify a user of a device in a particular location.
texts.text: In the worst cases, this information could be used to deliver targeted malware to your device. It could also be used to locate or identify a user of a device in a particular location.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Using temporary addresses
texts.text: Using temporary addresses

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most systems allow for  temporary addressing , and some even enable it by default. However, many Linux distributions do not enable temporary addresses by default.
texts.text: Most systems allow for  temporary addressing , and some even enable it by default. However, many Linux distributions do not enable temporary addresses by default.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There is a kernel tunable that controls temporary addressing on Linux systems:
texts.text: There is a kernel tunable that controls temporary addressing on Linux systems:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Do not use a temporary address
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 0
# Set a temporary address, but do not make it the default
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 1
# Set a temporary address and make it the default
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 2
texts.text:
# Do not use a temporary address
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 0
# Set a temporary address, but do not make it the default
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 1
# Set a temporary address and make it the default
net.ipv6.conf.all.use_tempaddr = 2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: NetworkManager can handle this setting as well. Just set the
texts.text: NetworkManager can handle this setting as well. Just set the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ipv6.ip6-privacy
texts.text: ipv6.ip6-privacy

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: variable to 0, 1, or 2. For example, to enable temporary adrr
texts.text: variable to 0, 1, or 2. For example, to enable temporary adrr

texts.label: code
texts.orig: nmcli connection modify eth0 ipv6.ip6-privacy 2
texts.text: nmcli connection modify eth0 ipv6.ip6-privacy 2

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: NetworkManager will activate this setting immediately and begin using the temporary address as the default.
texts.text: NetworkManager will activate this setting immediately and begin using the temporary address as the default.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Caveats
texts.text: Caveats

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Temporary addresses are built based on the MAC address and a random time string, so they will change from time to time. Avoid using temporary addressing on devices that you regularly access via their IPv6 address, such as servers or other non-mobile systems.
texts.text: Temporary addresses are built based on the MAC address and a random time string, so they will change from time to time. Avoid using temporary addressing on devices that you regularly access via their IPv6 address, such as servers or other non-mobile systems.
